title: ‘Anne Boleyn’ Review: Royal Bore
sub_head: Jodie Turner-Smith stars as the ill-fated queen in AMC+’s new series that hints at the contemporary drama surrounding Meghan Markle.
body:
Anne Boleyn, the second of the six wives of Henry VIII and the first to lose her head, has been regarded in many ways by many people: as a seductress, a usurper, an enemy of Catholicism, a champion of Protestantism and, inarguably, the mother of Elizabeth I. It has taken several hundred years for her to be able to provide a stand-in for Meghan Markle. But how else does one read the miniseries “Anne Boleyn”?
The English entertainment press isn’t exactly renowned for its delicacy, but when “Anne Boleyn” made its U.K. debut in June, several reviewers ignored any Markle allegories while taking pre-emptive umbrage at the idea that anyone would object to the casting of Jodie Turner-Smith, who is Black, as the infamous Anne. Colorblind casting, for all its obvious merits, is based on the notion that a convincing performance is more critical than historical accuracy (or mere tradition), that a performer’s race is less important than his or her dramatic gifts. But in the case of “Anne Boleyn,” Ms. Turner-Smith, playing opposite the ginger-bearded Prince Harry-lookalike Mark Stanley as Henry, is part of a production that seems to be using race as a provocation, especially since Anne exhibits many of the qualities that Markle-haters maliciously ascribe to the current Duchess of Sussex.
